A maintenance rover operates in a rugged terrain with several sensor outposts.
It begins its route at BaseCamp and is required to inspect OutpostX and OutpostY
exactly once. Additionally, the rover may choose to inspect RelayStation to gather
bonus diagnostic data, but this is optional. Movement between adjacent locations
takes 1 minute, and each inspection requires a full minute of stationary scanning.
The terrain is energy-intensive: each movement consumes 1 unit of battery, and the
rover starts with only 6 units. The inspection at RelayStation offers a diagnostic
reward, but only if all mandatory inspections are completed with more than two battery
units remaining. The map is as follows: BaseCamp connects to Fork1 and Fork2. Fork1
connects to OutpostX and RelayStation. Fork2 connects to OutpostY and RelayStation. 
The maximum time taken can not be more than 10 minutes.

% Locations: BaseCamp, Fork1, Fork2, OutpostX, OutpostY, RelayStation
loc("BaseCamp"; "Fork1"; "Fork2"; "OutpostX"; "OutpostY"; "RelayStation").

% Edges
edge("BaseCamp", "Fork1").
edge("BaseCamp", "Fork2").
edge("Fork1", "OutpostX").
edge("Fork1", "RelayStation").
edge("Fork2", "OutpostY").
edge("Fork2", "RelayStation").

% 10 Minutes maximum time.
time(0..10).

% The rover starts at BaseCamp.
at("BaseCamp", 0).

% Inspect OutpostX and OutpostY exactly once each.
1 { inspect_at("OutpostX", T) : time(T) } 1.
1 { inspect_at("OutpostY", T) : time(T) } 1.

% Moves between adjacent nodes takes 1 timestep.
1 { at(L, T) : loc(L) } 1 :- time(T).
:- at(L1, T), at(L2, T+1), not edge(L1, L2), not edge(L2, L1), L1 != L2.

% Each inspection requires 1 full timestep at the inspection site.
at(L, T) :- inspect_at(L, T).
at(L, T+1) :- inspect_at(L, T), T < 10.

% Each movement consumes 1 battery unit.
move(L1, L2, T) :- at(L1, T), at(L2, T+1), edge(L1, L2), L1 != L2.
used_battery(N, T) :- N = #count { T1 : move(_, _, T1), T1 < T }, time(T).

% The battery stores 6 units.
remaining_battery(N1, T) :- used_battery(N2, T), N1 = 6 - N2.

% Only allow inspection of RelayStation if there are >2 battery units once the other sites are scanned.
0 { inspect_at("RelayStation", T) : time(T) } 1.
:- inspect_at("RelayStation", _), remaining_battery(N, T), N <= 2, sites_scanned(T).
sites_scanned(T) :- T = #max { T1 : inspect_at(L, T1), L != "RelayStation"}.

**Exercise 4.12: Constrained Resource Allocation in Academic Scheduling**

Consider a scheduling problem involving a set of five distinct lectures, denoted by $\mathcal{L} = \{l_1, l_2, l_3, l_4, l_5\}$. Each lecture $l_i$ is associated with a specific subject $s \in \mathcal{S}$, where $\mathcal{S} = \{\text{Artificial Intelligence, Mathematics, Physics}\}$. 

The objective is to define a feasible assignment of these lectures into a spatio-temporal domain defined by:
1.  A set of discrete time slots $\mathcal{T} = \{t_{morning}, t_{afternoon}\}$.
2.  A set of physical venues $\mathcal{R} = \{r_1, r_2, r_3\}$.

Let an assignment be a function $\sigma: \mathcal{L} \to \mathcal{T} \times \mathcal{R}$, where each lecture is mapped to a unique (time, room) tuple. A valid schedule must satisfy the following formal conditions:

**Condition I: Resource Uniqueness (Injective Mapping)**
The mapping $\sigma$ must be injective with respect to the codomain $\mathcal{T} \times \mathcal{R}$. Formally, for any two distinct lectures $l_i, l_j \in \mathcal{L}$, $\sigma(l_i) \neq \sigma(l_j)$. This precludes the simultaneous occupancy of a single room by multiple lectures.

**Condition II: Subject-Based Spatial Exclusion**
Define a function $f: \mathcal{L} \to \mathcal{S}$ that maps each lecture to its respective subject. For any pair of lectures $(l_i, l_j)$, if $f(l_i) = \text{Mathematics}$ and $f(l_j) = \text{Physics}$, their assigned rooms must be disjoint, regardless of the temporal component. That is:
$$\text{proj}_{\mathcal{R}}(\sigma(l_i)) \neq \text{proj}_{\mathcal{R}}(\sigma(l_j))$$
where $\text{proj}_{\mathcal{R}}$ denotes the projection of the assignment onto the set of rooms.

**Task:**
1.  Represent this problem as a **Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP)**, identifying the variables, domains, and specific constraints.
2.  Determine the total number of possible configurations in the search space, ignoring constraints.
3.  Discuss how the subject-specific spatial exclusion constraint impacts the pruning of the search tree during a back-tracking search.

% There are 5 lectures to schedule.
lecture(1..5).

% Topics are: AI, Math, or Physics.
topic("AI"; "Math"; "Physics").
1 { topicOf(L, T) : topic(T) } 1 :- lecture(L).

% There are 3 rooms and 2 time slots: morning and afternoon.
room(1..3).
slot("morning"; "afternoon").

% Each lecture must be scheduled once.
1 { scheduled(L, R, S) : room(R), slot(S) } 1 :- lecture(L).

% Only one lecture per room-time.
:- scheduled(L1, R, S), scheduled(L2, R, S), L1 != L2.

% AI lectures must be in the morning.
:- scheduled(L, _, S), topicOf(L, "AI"), S != "morning".

% Math and Physics may not happen in the same room.
:- scheduled(L1, R, _), scheduled(L2, R, _), topicOf(L1, "Math"), topicOf(L2, "Physics").

We are currently finalizing the layout for our upcoming three-day symposium, which will feature a total of twelve workshops spread across four key disciplines: Artificial Intelligence, Physics, Mathematics, and Linguistics. The event is hosted in a venue with four rooms, and each day is structured into three distinct sessions consisting of a morning, a midday, and an evening slot. Every workshop needs to be assigned its own room and time, as we cannot allow for any double-bookings.

As we coordinate the space, we have to follow several logistical constraints to ensure the event runs smoothly. No single room can host more than two workshops on any given day, and to prevent burnout, we must ensure there is always a break between sessions; this means back-to-back bookings in the same room are not permitted. We also have some specific venue limitations to navigate, as Room 2 will be closed every evening, and Room 4 is not equipped to handle the technical requirements for AI or Physics sessions.

Thematically, each discipline has its own set of scheduling rules. All Artificial Intelligence workshops must be held during the morning sessions, while Physics presentations are restricted to the first two days and cannot take place on the final day of the event. Our Mathematics sessions are limited to being held in either Room 1 or Room 3. Linguistics workshops require a bit more breathing room, so we must ensure that no two Linguistics sessions ever run concurrently across the venue.

To keep the daily schedule organized, we’ve decided that each room should only host one specific discipline per day, meaning you won’t see different topics rotating through the same four walls within a single twenty-four-hour period. Furthermore, to provide a well-rounded experience for our attendees, we need to make sure that at least one workshop from each of the four disciplines is represented every day. We also have two specific requirements for our program's bookends: the very first workshop of the symposium must be an AI presentation, and the final session of the third day must be a Linguistics talk.

Our objective is to create a schedule that maximizes the use of our available rooms and time slots without overextending the staff or breaking any of these established rules. We want to fill as many of the available slots as the logic allows, ensuring the symposium is as robust as possible while respecting every constraint.

% Workshops and Topics
workshop(1..12).
topic("AI"; "Physics"; "Math"; "Linguistics").
1 { topicOf(W, T) : topic(T) } 1 :- workshop(W).

% Time and Structure
day(1..3).
slot("morning"; "midday"; "evening").
room(1..4).

% Every workshop must be scheduled
1 {scheduled(W, R, S, D) : room(R), slot(S), day(D)} :- workshop(W).

% Only one workshop per room per time
:- scheduled(W1, R, S, D), scheduled(W2, R, S, D), W1 != W2.

% At most 2 sessions per room per day
{scheduled(W, R, S, D) : workshop(W), slot(S)} 2 :- room(R), day(D).

% No room can be used in adjacent time slots
adjacent("morning", "midday").
adjacent("midday", "evening").
:- scheduled(_, R, S1, D), scheduled(_, R, S2, D), adjacent(S1, S2).

% Room 2 cannot be used in the evening
:- scheduled(_, 2, "evening", _).

% Room 4 cannot host AI or Physics
:- scheduled(W, 4, _, _), topicOf(W, "AI").
:- scheduled(W, 4, _, _), topicOf(W, "Physics").

% AI workshops must be in the morning
:- scheduled(W, _, S, _), topicOf(W, "AI"), S != "morning".

% Physics workshops must be held on the first or second day
:- scheduled(W, _, _, D), topicOf(W, "Physics"), D = 3.

% All Math workshops must be scheduled in Room 1 or Room 3
:- scheduled(W, R, _, _), topicOf(W, "Math"), R != 1, R != 3.

% Linguistics workshops must not overlap in time
:- scheduled(W1, _, S, D), scheduled(W2, _, S, D), topicOf(W1, "Linguistics"),
topicOf(W2, "Linguistics"), W1 != W2.

% No room may host workshops from different topics on the same day
:- scheduled(W1, R, _, D), scheduled(W2, R, _, D), topicOf(W1, T1),
topicOf(W2, T2), T1 != T2.

% At least one workshop per topic must occur each day
:- day(D), topic(T), not scheduled(_, _, _, D) : topicOf(_, T).

% Time encoding for total ordering
slotOrder("morning", 1).
slotOrder("midday", 2).
slotOrder("evening", 3).

% Compute time index
timeIndex(D, S, I) :- day(D), slot(S), slotOrder(S, O), I = (D - 1) * 3 + O.

% Assign each scheduled workshop its time index
wTime(W, I) :- scheduled(W, _, S, D), timeIndex(D, S, I).

% Find the minimum and maximum index among all scheduled workshops
minTime(I) :- I = #min {J : wTime(_, J)}.
maxTime(I) :- I = #max {J : wTime(_, J)}.

% First workshop must be AI
:- wTime(W, I), minTime(I), not topicOf(W, "AI").

% Last workshop must be Linguistics
:- wTime(W, I), maxTime(I), not topicOf(W, "Linguistics").

% Maximize the number of rooms used in each time slot
used(R, S, D) :- scheduled(_, R, S, D).
roomsUsed(N, S, D) :- N = #count{R : used(R, S, D)}, slot(S), day(D).
#maximize {N : roomsUsed(N, S, D)}.

% Minimize idle slots
idle(R, S, D) :- room(R), slot(S), day(D), not used(R, S, D).
num_idle(N) :- N = #count{R, S, D: idle(R, S, D) }.
#minimize { N: num_idle(N) }.
